“Nothing is too wonderful to be true, if it be consistent with the laws of nature”

— Michael Faraday

The Earth moves around the Sun at a speed of about 100.000 Km/h, which is approximately 30.000 meters each second.


Just for context, the fastest vehicle in the world, which is an aircraft called NASA X-43, can reach a speed of about 12.000 Km/h. That’s barely 10% of the earth's speed around the sun.


Motion is present in everything we do, and it goes way beyond walking, driving, and flying, motion can be used to describe the orbit of a planet and even the orbit of an electron around the core of an atom.


Motion also takes many forms and shapes.


We have oscillatory motion, referring to the motion of particles that go back and forth repeatedly.


We also have at our disposal periodic motion, which can be used to describe the motion of planets and every motion that repeats itself after some time interval.


Random motion is one of the most interesting types of motion since we currently don't have ways of predicting the motion of an object.


Imagine a paper being dropped from any height, we won't be able to come up with an equation that will describe the path of the paper.


But since we are only talking about motion in one dimension we are going to leave those subjects for future learning since the topics wander beyond our current scope.


Today we have a solid understanding of pretty much all the laws of motion.


But it wasn't always like this.


“In the absence of air resistance, all bodies fall with the same acceleration, independent of their mass”.


This is the famous quote representing the theory of Galileo regarding the free-falling of objects.


Although Galileo could not see his experiment in action because of the technological limitations of his time, his theory proved to be right many years later.


Newton also contributed a great deal to motion with his laws.


Perhaps it is safe to say that today we rest on the shoulders of giants.


And it's our duty as a civilization to continue to thrive for more and more understanding of our universe and life.


And what better way to start this than by comprehending all the basic foundations of kinematics?


Displacement


Displacement can be defined as the difference in position regarding the initial position where the object started.


But before going even deeper into understanding displacement, we must always have a frame of reference in our minds, because this will help us practically illustrate the problem.


As I mentioned, a frame of reference is simply an easy way to locate the position of an object relative to a reference point.


As humans, we can always visualize the problem in our heads, but in physics, it is really common to use a set of coordinate axes.



In most cases, when we are describing a person walking either east or west we tend to use the x-axis. On the other hand, when we are illustrating some object falling we use the y-axis.


So we can define displacement as the difference between the final and the initial position of an object.


Mathematically, we can represent this with the following formula:



Where x2 refers to the final position, and x1 refers to the initial position


Let’s understand this further with an example:


A person drives 10 km east from his starting point, then 5 km west.


Based on our definitions of displacement, it is safe to say that the displacement is 5 km since the person ended 5 kilometers away from the initial position.



Let's verify this further by plugging the values directly into the formula.



It is also important to point out that displacement differs from the total distance traveled.


As the name suggests, the total distance refers to the entire path covered by the object, and displacement is how far the object is from its origin point.


Based on our example, the total distance covered by the person driving the car is 15 km.


Now that we understand what displacement is, you might be wondering how we go about solving actual problems.


Well, let's do this.


Imagine a dog starting at x = 25 m on a coordinate space and after walking along the x-axis he ends up on x = -15 m. It then turns around and walks back again ending up on x = 5 m. Determine the dog’s displacement and the total distance traveled by the dog.



Average Velocity


Motion is a huge part of physics, back in the 1500s and 1600s big names like Isaac Newton and Galileo Galilei were laying the foundation for our understanding of motion.


As we know motion is directly tied to our lives, almost everything we do revolves around motion, walking, driving, running, you name it.


Consequently, motion and velocity work together just like hammer and nail.


In our everyday lives, the terms velocity and speed are often used as the same thing.


But when we are trying to comprehend the laws of physics we must make a distinction between velocity and speed.


Velocity refers to the displacement of an object divided by the elapsed time. We already know that displacement is the difference between the final and initial position of an object.



On the other hand, speed or average speed can be defined as the total distance traveled by an object divided by the total time. If a truck travels 250 km in 5 hours we can say that the average speed of the truck is 50 km/h.



Let's go a little deeper with our same dog example.


The dog started on x = 25 m, then he walked along the horizontal axis and ended up on x = -15 m, finally the dog circles around and stopped on x = 5 m. Imagine that the total time was 20 seconds.


Let's start with the average speed.



We know first that the dog started on x = 25 m and went to x = -15 m, which gives us 40 m walked.


Then from x = -15 m, he went back to x = 5 m, which gives us 20 m.


Adding 40 m to 20 m gives us 60 m.


Applying the average speed formula, we can figure out that the average speed of the dog is 3 m/s.


Since we are talking about the average speed we don't need to worry about the negative signs because we only care about the total distance covered by the dog.


But now this changes a bit when calculating the average velocity.


We know for certain that the dog started on x = 25 m (initial position) and ended up on x = 5 m (final position).



In this context, we only need to worry about the final position relative to the origin point.


Applying the average velocity formula we get:


Displacement = 5 m - 25 m = -20 m


Dividing our displacement by the total time the dog took we get our average velocity of -1 m/s.


The answer is negative because according to our frame of reference, the dog walked back in the negative direction.


Acceleration


Now that we understand the laws of velocity we can start to look at acceleration since it is directly tied to velocity.


An object is said to be accelerating whenever a change in velocity occurs


Putting in more formal terms, acceleration can be defined as the change in velocity divided by a time interval.


This means that when we say an object has an acceleration 5 m/s2 we are basically saying the object accelerates 5 m/s each second. That also explains why the second unit is squared on acceleration.



We can represent more precisely this relationship between the velocity and time in this formula:



There will be times when physics problems will involve a bunch of terms like velocity, position, time, and acceleration.


It is important to point out that we are talking about constant acceleration, in other words, the change in velocity stays the same. If we say that a particle has an acceleration of 5 m/s2 this acceleration will be the same throughout the entire motion.


So for that, we will need to find useful equations that will allow us to solve any problem related to constant acceleration.


In most kinematics problems related to motion, we want to find the velocity after a given time. For instance, we might want to know the velocity of a car after 15 seconds.


To achieve that we can simply grab our previous acceleration equation and solve for “v” giving us:



Sometimes we might also want to know the position of an object after a given time.



Now you might be wondering the situations in which time is not known or we do not care about the time. Well for that we have this one:



All three formulas above relate velocity, acceleration, position, and time.


At this point in our learning, you have all the building blocks necessary to solve any kinematics problem that appears in your way.


For reference, below there are all the useful kinematics equations for constant acceleration.



Freefall objects


This happened many years before Galileo’s time.


Just like people believed that the Sun orbits the Earth.


People also used to believe that heavier objects fall faster than lighter objects because of their mass.


But now we can safely conclude that the speed of a falling object is not proportional to its mass.


Galileo idealized a scenario in which, in the absence of air resistance all the objects would fall at the same speed.


If I said that objects will float because angels hold them, then I will need to develop ways of testing my theory.


In the scientific world, a theory that cannot be tested is considered less scientific because it lacks empirical evidence.


Although Galileo had some technological limitations for his time, he knew that.


That's why he idealized a scenario in which, in the absence of air resistance all the objects would fall at the same speed.


It is nice when a theory can be tested, so to support his ideas he used the following demonstration and argument:


A rock dropped from a height of 2 meters will have a larger impact on the ground than the same rock dropped from a height of 0.3 meters, for that to happen the first rock must be at a higher speed.


As I mentioned before, Galileo developed an experiment where we put a rock and a feather on a tube.


For the first scenario the tube is filled with air then the rock and the feather are dropped at the same time, and the rock obviously hits the ground first.


But this changes in the next experiment.


Interestingly enough, when we remove all the air from the tube, after releasing the rock and the feather at the same time we confirm that both objects fall at the same speed.


Hitting the floor at the same time.



You can check the real experiment by clicking here [insert link here]


At this point in our learning, we are forgetting the most important aspect.


What is this “speed” that makes all objects fall towards the center of Earth?


Well, my friend, this acceleration is caused by Gravity.



Gravity is present in many topics in physics, it's basically the foundation of our universe, and it's extremely unlikely that we are going to fully understand or solve it anytime soon. Because of that, I will create a separate article in the near future.


For now, you just need to know that when we drop an object, the force of gravity makes the object accelerate at a rate of 9.8 m/s2 towards the center of Earth.


The million-dollar question now is:


Can we use our kinematics formulas from before to solve free-falling problems?


Well, dear reader, the answer is YES!


Let's solve one right now.


A person throws a ball upward with an initial velocity of 20 m/s. Calculate how high it goes.


Right from the start this problem tells us two things:


— The first one is that it wants to know the position.


— The second is the initial velocity of the ball right when it leaves the person’s hand.


Equipped with this knowledge, we can now draw a diagram illustrating the problem.



Point A is where the ball leaves the person's hand with an initial velocity of 20 meters per second.


Between point A and point B, we have a downward acceleration caused by gravity which makes the speed of the ball decrease.


Since gravity is pulling downward we will have a negative value for our acceleration.


The problem is asking us to calculate the maximum height of the ball.


We only worry about the A and B intervals.


We consider the acceleration caused by gravity negative because is pointing downwards.


$$ { a = -g = -9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2 } $$


As the ball goes up, its speed decreases until it reaches the highest point where the speed is zero.


So now we possess the current quantities:


$$ { a = -9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2} $$


$$ { V_0 = 20 \, \text{m/s}} $$


$$ { V = 20 \, \text{m/s}} $$


With only those quantities we can pick the equation that best fits our current problem that we are solving.



How to solve physics problems


Whether you are meaning to pass your next exam or trying to master the field of physics, learning how to solve problems in the most efficient way is crucial for any physics student.


For a long time, I thought that solving a physics problem was about finding the right equation to insert the values. Perhaps at the end of the day, this is not wrong, but it can surely lead you to the wrong path if your goal is to understand physics.


I noticed my perception of solving problems was completely out of place, I was finding the right answers but I would never understand why I was using a given formula or why certain steps were taken.


An equation is just really a way of numerically representing a correct approximation of a problem, the goal of the equation is not to make you understand physics


Instead of trying to find some equation to fill in the values, we need to change our perception of looking at physics problems and instead develop an approach that will make us not only find the correct answer but also understand the core ideas and concepts of the problem.


1) Understand the problem


Before trying any problem we must first understand, and that goes for all areas of life.


You won't be able to navigate through a problem without understanding it first. For this first part, I recommend that you read carefully the problem and write down what the problem is asking.


If a problem asks “How long does it take?”, you know the final answer should be in time units, or “How far an object will be?”, the answer will be in length units.


You should be familiar with these terms.


2) Illustrate the problem in any way possible


Our brains process visual information better than text, especially when solving a physics question. Draw a chart, diagram, graph, or any visual aid that will help you solidify the concepts.


It doesn't need to be scientifically correct as long as you understand.


3) Gather all the given quantities


Go through the problem again and take notes of the values given.


After that, you will need to interpret the values, as well as what the problem is asking, to write them into physical form.


For instance, when a velocity problem states “an object starts from rest” this means that the initial velocity is 0.


Based on the given quantities you will hopefully have some idea of what approach to take for solving the problem.


4) Plan an approach


This is the section in which you will know what the problem wants and the principles involved and with that, you will be able to pick an equation or a method that suits the best.


5) Carry out the calculations


If you followed all the steps above correctly, this is the easiest part. Simply plug the quantities into the formula and solve algebraically for the desired value.


After you are done, give some thought to the final result and ask yourself: Does this final result make sense? Are the units correct? Is there any way in which I can verify my result?


At the end of the day, all this work you’ve done to solve the problem will pay out, not only for your understanding but also for explaining your thought process to a teacher or classmate.


Wrapping Up


As I said at the beginning of our journey, nowadays we rest on the shoulders of giants, and it's our duty to complete the work they started and push beyond the limits.


See you next time!

"Physics is really nothing more than a search for ultimate simplicity, but so far all we have is a kind of elegant messiness."

— Bill Bryson

Whenever we mention human evolution we tend to imagine humans as a multi-planetary species or a dystopian future like Blade Runner governed by AI robots with flying cars.


But we do not need to go that deep to talk about this matter, sometimes simple things like counting objects or measuring the length of a bar already make a huge difference in the grand scheme of things.


Human evolution, specifically in the field of agriculture, brought the necessity of measuring and counting things.


This is when people first started seeing the need for something that once didn't exist.


In the course of human history, there were a lot of measurement systems depending on the culture, each system adapted to its own necessities.


There was the Chinese system, Egyptian system, Roman system, you get the point.


But they all had one goal in mind, measure or count something.


In physics, or any other science, the goal is to understand the chaos and hidden layers around us through observations and careful measurement.


Physics can be described as a creative field, to prove new theories and increase our understanding of the world we must have room to experiment.


Every theory that we have, came from imagination. Take for instance the atomic theory, which states that every element in the universe is composed of tiny little dots called atoms.


Scientists did not come up with this theory by observing atoms, since we can't see them, in fact, this theory was the pure consequence of creative thoughts.


This is one of the reasons why physics is considered a creative field.


Along with those experiments, also comes the need for rules about how things are measured.


Much later, as technology was starting to evolve, accuracy and precision became even more necessary, so humans needed to figure out a way to standardize how things were measured.


That's when the International System of Units comes into play.


The International System Of Units


Today, every country that you visit has a different currency, Dollar, Euro, Indian Ruppe, and so on.


Now imagine if every country that you visited had different units for measuring. That was the deal back in the day.


One country has a different unit for length, another country has a different unit for measuring mass, you get the idea.


You don't need me to tell you that this can get confusing very quickly.


In the 70s the General Conference on Weights and Measures decided to establish a comprehensive specification for units of measurement.


Picking seven quantities as base quantities, forming the new SI.



As technology was getting advanced and humankind had already landed on the moon, they needed a practical way to deal with units and measurements.


And this practical way came in the form of something that was developed more than 1500 years ago by a man called Archimedes.


Scientific Notation


Do you wish to represent the distance between two galaxies?


Use scientific notation


Do you want to represent the radius of a proton?


Use scientific notation


The purpose of scientific notation is to represent numbers that are either too large or too small to be written, just like the two examples from before.


Scientific notation is usually in the 'powers of ten'


Coming back to our galaxy example, if we wish to represent the distance in meters between the Andromeda galaxy to our Milky Way galaxy, here goes the number:


$$ {24000000000000000000000} $$


There is absolutely no way that this is something practical, imagine all the work if we needed to include a number like this in our calculations, instead, it is better to use scientific notation:


$$ {2.4 \times {10}^{22}} $$


Changing Units


I once heard someone ask how to convert square meters to cubic meters.


Jesus did that with water when he turned it into wine.


We can't achieve this yet.


What we can do is convert units that are on the same physical quantity, like length, time, and mass.


We do this by taking advantage of a famous method called chain-link conversion.


To achieve this conversion we multiply our current measure by a conversion factor.


For instance, because 1 meter and 100 centimeters are basically the same length intervals represented in different units, we have a conversion unit.


As you can see in the illustration below, the unwanted factors 'cancel' each other leaving us with only the desired unit. In this case the centimeter.



Length


Throughout history, the meter has been defined in a bunch of different ways.



Back in the 1800s, the meter was defined as one ten-millionth of the distance from the north pole to the equator. Which is equivalent to 1 divided by 10000000.


As you can imagine, this decision for the meter wasn't the most practical.


So they decided to define the meter as the distance between two lines engraved in a platinum-iridium bar.


Since the meter was defined based on a physical object, you can picture the material being subject to temperature, air conditions, and physical damage.


Also, with the advancements being made in quantum physics, they would definitely need a more precise definition, a sort of universal definition.


Then it was later defined as 165076373 wavelengths of an orange-red light emitted by atoms of Krypton-86 in a gas discharge tube.


Why did they choose this awkward number? Dont know.


Just kidding, it was because the new standard would be somewhat equal to the old meter bar standard.


But guess what?


Even more precision was required.


This time around, they needed something constant, a way of universally measuring things, allowing room for accuracy on multiple different branches of physics.


Now this definition resides until today:


' The meter is defined as the distance of the path traveled by light in the vacuum during a time interval of 1/299 792 458 of a second.'



This time interval was purposely chosen based on the speed of light. Since the speed of light is a universal constant and is not subjected to variations like temperature, pressure, or any gradual change over time.


$$ {c = 299\,792\,458 \, \text{m/s}} $$


Time


Some people say that the concept of ‘time’ is just for organizational purposes, like knowing what time to go to bed, what time to wake up, what time to eat, and so on.


While others say that time is the fourth dimension, something that as humans we have yet to understand. Like thinking of time as a physical quantity, but since we don't want to lose ourselves, let's leave this topic for another occasion.



Based on those definitions, in physics, ‘time’ has two roads:


The normal everyday stuff, which you need to know in order to get through your day.


And the scientific road, where time is in terms of 'how long an event lasts' or 'when did it happen'.


A pretty simple example of this is the dawn of the universe which has thought-provoking questions like 'When did the universe begin?' or 'For how long does the universe exist? Was there anything before the Big Bang? '.


Any topic like this always raises those fundamental questions that can leave you with an existential crisis.


As you can imagine, what happened to the standard length model, also happened to the time standard model.


In the beginning, scientists were using a quartz clock, in which inside was a quartz crystal that vibrated naturally, this vibration was used to keep track of time.


We’ve had 10-hour days, 12-hour days, you named.


But it was necessary a better and more precise time standard as technology changes rapidly.


To meet the requirements of the technological advancements being made, atomic clocks were developed.


So since the late 60s, the second has been based on an atomic clock that uses the difference of energy between the two lowest states of energy in a cesium-133 atom.


When the atoms are hit with microwaves in the correct frequency, the Cesium atoms go through transitions from one state to another.


One second is defined as the time taken by 9192631770 cycles of this radiation.



Mass


How can you know how much something weighs?


Well, you put it on a scale?


Hmm, okay.


But how does the scale know the weight of an object?


Well, basically it's an object that gets compared to another object that gets compared to another object, of course, there is a more complex explanation that involves a load cell that once a force is applied sends an electrical signal that is used to calculate the weight based on the load cell’s bend.


But this is currently not necessary to understand mass and its definitions, so let's continue here.


The standard unit for mass is the kilogram (kg), and it is defined based on a platinum-iridium bar, and it is kept near Paris.


As we can recall, the meter was once defined as the distance engraved on a platinum bar.


The second was once defined based on the motion of the Earth.


Candela was defined in terms of the brightness of a specific type of candle flame.


You can start to see a pattern here, those definitions were all based on physical objects.


The standard unit for mass was the only unit whose definition is still based on a man-made object.


But this changed recently.


And up until May 2019, the kilogram was defined as a platinum-iridium cylinder.


This old definition was due to change, and they knew that.


They needed a definition that would not change with time, nor be subject to physical variations like corrosion, maybe a constant dwelling in nature.


And they choose Planck’s constant for that.


'The kilogram, symbol kg, is the SI unit of mass. It is defined by taking the fixed numerical value of the Planck constant h to be 6.62607015×10−34 when expressed in the unit J⋅s, which is equal to kg⋅m2⋅s−1, where the meter and the second are defined in terms of c and ΔνCs.'


Wait what?


But how is the mass related to Planck’s constant you may wonder?


Let's take a step back here to really understand this.


For starters, Planck’s constant will now be set to a fixed value, which is:


$$ { 6.62607015 \times 10^{-34} \, \text{m}^2 \, \text{kg/s}} $$


So from now on, scientists can somewhat safely obtain the mass of a kilogram in terms of Planck’s constant.


All of this is possible because of a measurement instrument called the kibble balance (formerly known as the watt balance) named after its inventor Bryan Kibble.


This allows the comparison of electrical power with mechanical power by equalling the mechanical energy exerted by the mass of an object with an equivalent amount of electrical energy.


The Kibble Balance operates in two ways:



The first way is called the force mode, in which the Kibble balance magnetically levitates the mass object. The test mass exerts a downward force, which is equal to its mass (m) times the local gravity (g).


Then the current applied to the coil is adjusted until the upward force on the coil precisely matches the downward force, when this equilibrium is reached the current is recorded.


We are able to calculate the force with the following equation:


$$ { F = I \cdot B \cdot L } $$


Where I is the current, B is the magnetic field force, and L is the strength of the wire in the coil.


But since the product of BL is hard to measure, physics provided another way around using induction.


A voltage is induced in a conductor when it travels through a magnetic field, and this voltage is exactly proportional to the field strength and the velocity.


This allows for a second operation called 'velocity mode'.



In velocity mode, the test mass is removed from the balance and the coil is moved at a constant velocity. After that, the resulting induced voltage is measured.


We can measure the induced voltage with


$$ { V = v \cdot B \cdot L } $$


where B and L are the exact quantities from before and v is the velocity.


After we combine both equations, the B and L cancel out, leaving us with the following:


$$ { I \cdot V = m \cdot g \cdot V } $$


Electrical power equals mechanical power. We can also solve for mass:


$$ { m = \frac{I \cdot V}{g \cdot v} } $$


But wait, you might be wondering, from where does the Plancks constant come into all of this?


Let me answer that for you.


According to Einstein’s equations of relativity, we know that mass can be quantified in terms of energy, and Planck’s equation states that energy can be converted in terms of the frequency of photons, for instance.


When we take the two equations together we are able to observe that mass, is deeply related to h, which is used to describe the small energy content of individual photons emitted by atoms in hot objects.


To summarize the whole thing, any energy measurement is a mass measurement.


The study of measurement and units allowed us to move away from the physical object definitions and instead stick with constants.


So now the standard unit for mass is defined in terms of the Planck constant, not tied anymore with an imperfect man-made artifact.


So now, the Earth and everything around us could disappear and you would still be able to calculate the mass of an object, with the right tools, anywhere in the universe.


Wrapping Up


The universe has been around for quite some time now, and it's always remarkable to witness such advancements in human history. How different branches of human knowledge can come together and develop ways of measuring objects and define standard units for those measures.


From a metal bar to the speed of light and from a platinum-iridium cylinder to Planck’s constant. Incredible stuff.


But is it really enough for the coming years? Will we need to update any of those definitions mentioned above? Will we be able to reconcile quantum mechanics with relativity?


I guess that only time will be able to answer those questions.


And now I will leave you with the following quote by Aristotle:


'We need to use our senses to make sense of reality'

This simplicity comes in form of measures and units. But how does all of this helps us comprehend the laws of the universe? Let's check it out.

“I can calculate the motion of heavenly bodies, but not the madness of people”


This quote reveals how well Newton understood about the physical universe and how little he understood about the complex nature of human behavior.


I think is safe to say that Sir Isaac Newton is one of the most important people that have contributed to science, physics, and mathematics.


Newton's laws explain practically all the things in our everyday lives that we take for granted, like walking, sitting, driving, running, and so on.


They describe motion, the causes of motion, and every aspect related to the subject.


Newton’s laws are often described as three separate laws, but when we zoom out and look at the big picture we can see that they are actually pretty close to each other, without the first one we wouldn't have the second one, and without the second one we wouldn't have the third one.


Like an old friend of mine used to say: ”They are connecting to each other”

So make yourself balanced and let's learn about Newton’s laws.


First Law


“If the net force on a body is zero the velocity will not change.”


An object at rest remains at rest, and an object in motion remains in motion at a constant speed and in a straight line unless acted on by an unbalanced force.


In other words, objects tend to keep doing what they are doing. Imagine a ball, if the ball is moving it tends to stay moving, and if the ball is stopped tends to stay stopped.


In the context of the ball, the unbalanced forces would be the friction between the ball and the ground and the air resistance, eventually stopping the ball.


So, if there was no friction between the ball and the ground and the resistance of the air was zero, the ball would just move forever at a constant speed on a straight line.


This law is often referred to as the Law of Inertia.


To get an object to move you must first overcome the Inertia.


This may sound silly but have you ever wondered why it is easier to push a bike compared to pushing a truck?


Well, the answer lies in Inertia


But what is Inertia?


Inertia is the tendency of an object to resist changes in a state of motion


Inertia is the reason why it is easier to push a bike compared to pushing a truck. Inertia is also the reason why an object tends to keep doing what is doing.


To move anything, you must first overcome Inertia.


Here are a few examples:


At the beginning of a game of soccer, the ball will stay will the middle of the field unless the player makes the first kick, in other words, an unbalanced force will act on the ball.


Another common example in our everyday lives is when we suddenly hit the brakes on the car, the Inertia of our body tends to move us forward even after the car is stopped, according to Newton’s first law.


That leads us directly to the second law.


Second Law


“The acceleration of an object depends on the object's mass and the amount of force applied.”


According to Newton's second law, to move an object we need to apply some force to the object, causing the object to accelerate.


And since mass is also involved, to move an object with a larger mass we need a higher acceleration.


Here is the formula:


$$ { \sum F = m \cdot a } $$


Where F is the total or net force on a given system, m is the mass of the body, and a is the acceleration.


The total force on a body is equal to the product of the body’s mass and its acceleration.


As we can see, the acceleration of an object depends directly on the force applied.


It's essential to notice that for this law to be applicable, the mass of the object must be constant.


Here are some examples:


In the supermarket, we notice that is easier to push the cart when it's empty, that's because as the cart gets filled with more stuff the mass increases, and that requires a greater force to accelerate the cart.


As I mentioned earlier, this also applies to moving a bike compared to moving a truck, the bike has less mass so it is easier to push, while the truck has much more mass so it will require a lot of force in order to accelerate.


Third Law


“For every action, there is always an equal and opposite reaction”


The third law explains why when we start riding a bike we go forward instead of backward or in any other direction.


When we drop a ball on the ground the ball exerts a force on the ground, that's the action, and the ground immediately reacts by exerting another equal force on the ball in the opposite direction.


So a better definition for Newton’s third law would be: For every force, there is an equal and opposite force.


Since the forces are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction.


Picture the Earth orbiting the Sun, the Sun is more massive than the Earth, yet both exert the same force on each other.


Conclusion


Throughout this article we noticed that Newton’s laws are not just mere concepts or formulas that we find in a boring textbook in your grandma's bookshelf, they are actual principles that shape our daily lives and the world around us.


That’s what is awesome about those laws.


Understanding those laws is like achieving the maximum level on a game, making you aware of every single action, response, and principle of that game


It's important to mention that Newton’s laws are excellent for modeling our real-world experiences, but they do have some limitations.


Those limitations happen when a given object starts to approach the speed of light or is on the atomic scale.


If an object does not have a constant mass, or it is traveling close to the speed of light we need to consider relativity, so the laws of Newton no longer fit the situation.


For the sake of revision:


First law: An object at rest remains at rest, and an object in motion remains in motion at constant speed and in a straight line unless acted on by an unbalanced force.


Second law: The acceleration of an object depends on the object's mass and the amount of force applied.


Third law: Whenever one object exerts a force on another object, the second object exerts an equal and opposite force on the first.

The universe as we know is more than 13 billion years old.


Just so you know the difference between a million and a billion, a million seconds is around 12 days. On the other hand, a billion seconds is approximately 32 years. Big difference.


When we take a look at the cosmic scale, we can say for sure that humanity is pretty young when we really stop to look at the time.


Historical Context


The Kardashev Scale was born when the Russian/Soviet Astrophysicist Nikolai Kardashev was trying to comprehend life outside earth.


He noticed that if we could determine the amount of energy that some species consume, we can know their technological advancements.


And if we know the technological advancement of a species we can develop a method to measure that.


So The Kardashev Scale was created.


A method of measuring the level of a civilization based on the amount of energy that the civilization consumes.


Those civilizations range from extracting all the energy available from their planet, to colonizing galaxies and using black holes as sources of energy.


Pretty cool right?


So let's take a brief look at the main types of civilizations.


A Type 1 civilization is able to harness all the energy at a planetary level.


A Type 2 civilization on the other hand, is capable of extracting all the energy from their star and planetary system.


And a Type 3, is able to use all the energy available in their current galaxy.


It is important to notice that the scale goes on and on, but for the sake of our understanding of the universe, let's keep this list short.


So get in your spaceships and let's look at these civilizations.


Type 1


I am going to start by breaking your heart, the human race has not reached Type 1 yet.


We are still using energy resources from dead animals and plants.


Humanity has come a long way, in the past 200 years we went from extreme poverty to putting a man on the moon.


Still, we have a long road until we reach Type 1.


But what a Type 1 civilization would look like you might ask


Well, for starters, a Type 1 civilization would be able to completely shift the weather as it sees fit.


At the same time, the civilization would have total control over natural events such as volcanoes, earthquakes, hurricanes, and so on.


In other words, harnessing all the energy available from their planet and outside sources from the earth, like the sun energy.


A civilization like that would also be able to achieve amazing stuff like change the weather, control pollution, bring back extinct animals, recreate ecosystems, and much more.


In summary, they would be able to control anything on a planetary level.


Type 2


Type 2 civilizations are also known as “stellar civilizations”, since they are able to harness all the energy from their planetary system.


Here is when things start to get interesting.


Even though humanity will only reach Type 2 civilization in the next thousand years we can still picture what that would look like.


A Dyson Structure is a device built around the sun with the purpose of gathering all the energy available from the sun. This device was first presented by Freeman Dyson.


Imagine a gigantic hollow sphere built around the sun, that's what a Dyson sphere is.


With that amount of energy a Type 2 civilization might be able to perform space travels, terraforming planets, mine asteroids, achieving amazing breakthroughs in biology, physics, engineering, medicine, chemistry, and so on.


Hypothetically, a Type 2 civilization would be able to completely take over the entire planetary system, performing space travels, gathering resources, building massive structures on planets, and achieving all kinds of breakthroughs.


But again, this is child play compared to a Type 3 civilization.


Type 3


Civilizations of Type 3 are capable of using all the energy available from their galaxy.


Just for context, the milky way is around 100.000 light years in diameter. In only one year, light can travel a distance of 9.5 trillion kilometers, you can do the math, that is way too big.


Our radio transmissions go as far as 200 light years, that's nothing compared to the size of the milky way.


But believe if you want, a Type 3 civilization is able to control the energy of its entire galaxy.


How? That’s a question for our future descendents.


A civilization of this magnitude would be able to harness energy from black holes, move planets, perform interstellar travels, send messages to the other side of the galaxy, you name it.


A galaxy would be like a white canvas for them, ready to be painted as they wish.


Perhaps those types of civilizations are beyond our current understanding of the universe, or perhaps they don't even exist, and that is either scary or awesome because we might be the first ones to reach this kind of level.


We might have some problems on the way


In life, not everything happens as we expect.


This is precisely true for human civilization. Because, as we know, throughout the entire span of time, earth has faced multiple events like asteroid collision, glacial ages, extinctions, the list goes on.


Before we even think about other planets, we must solve problems right here on earth, otherwise we won't be able to evolve if we go extinct in the next 100 to 200 years.


And for the first time in history we have the power to destroy ourselves.


The Kardashev Scale shines light on a bright future ahead of us with countless possibilities, but let's not forget that everything begins right here on earth.

Humans built computers to expand our brains. Initially, scientists created computers to perform mathematical operations or repetitive tasks, but they ended up being extremely useful for various other things, such as problem-solving, communication, artificial intelligence, and more.


All of this is based on just zeros and ones (0, 1). With the advancement of technology, computers have become increasingly powerful in a very short period. To put it into perspective, the Apollo moon landing could be accomplished using a few Nintendo consoles.


With this in mind, you might be wondering what Computer Science is and what it studies. Computer Science studies what computers can do, covering a wide range of subjects. In this article, I will divide it into three parts: theory, computer engineering, and applications.


Some Historical Context


To begin, let's start with the father of Computer Science, Alan Turing. He developed the concept called the Turing Machine, which is a concept given to a computer that can be used for various things. Eventually, people created new designs for computers, but these designs are all equivalent to a Turing Machine.


A Turing Machine is composed of a long tape containing symbols, the central part (head) that can read and write symbols on the tape, and the register that stores information along with a list of instructions.


Today, the tape is like a computer's memory (RAM) and the head is the CPU. Lambda Calculus is used in computers as the basis for programming languages.


Computability Theory


This is an area of mathematics and computer science that seeks to perform procedures effectively following a set of rules. This theory classifies problems that, due to their own nature, can or cannot be solved.


An example of this is the Halting Problem, which tries to predict whether a program will stop functioning or continue running forever.


Computational Complexity


Another area of Computer Science is computational complexity. Computational complexity aims to classify and compare the difficulty of solving problems.


There are problems that can theoretically be solved, but they require enormous computational power and would take more time than the age of the universe. Therefore, computational complexity attempts to classify these problems.


There are several real-world problems that fall into this category. Scientists have various tricks to approximate these answers, but it’s never certain if these answers are the best ones.


Algorithms


An algorithm is a set of instructions designed to solve a specific problem. An algorithm is like a recipe for baking a cake.


One of the main goals of an algorithm is to perform a task or solve a problem as efficiently as possible, meaning as quickly as possible. Different algorithms may arrive at the same result in different times, and this is studied in algorithm complexity.


Information Theory


Information theory is another area of computer science that studies the properties of information and how this information can be stored, measured, and shared.


An example of this is how much you can compress information, making it occupy less memory while preserving the information completely. You can learn more about this in the theory of codes.


Cryptography


We use cryptography in messaging apps every day. Cryptography is extremely important when it comes to securely sending information over the internet.


There are various types of cryptography that use complex mathematical operations to keep information secure.


Graph Theory


In mathematics and computer science, graph theory is the branch that studies graphs, a mathematical structure used to represent relationships between objects or information. A set of vertices is connected by edges or lines, forming a graph.


Data Structures


In computing, data structures are a way of storing and managing information with the goal of accessing and modifying information efficiently.


Some examples of data structures are arrays, stacks, hash tables, queues, heaps, graphs, and linked lists.


Computational Geometry


Computational geometry is another area of computer science that involves the creation, analysis, and implementation of efficient algorithms for solving geometric problems.


To keep it clear, there are several other areas that I haven’t mentioned to avoid making the article too long. Examples of these areas include quantum computing, parallel and distributed programming, and much more.


Computer Engineering


In today’s world, computers are required to do hundreds of things at the same time, which can be a challenge in computer development. Therefore, scientists need to create them to be fast and efficient.


Any task you perform on a computer goes through the CPU. When you perform multiple tasks simultaneously, the CPU needs to switch between these tasks to complete them as quickly as possible, and this is controlled by a scheduler, whose main function is to optimize task execution.


Computer Architecture


In computing, computer architecture is a set of rules and methods that describe implementations, functionalities, and the organization of systems. Basically, it is how a processor is developed to perform certain tasks.


CPUs serve a general purpose, GPUs are implemented in graphics, and FPGAs can be programmed to be extremely fast for a specific set of activities.


Softwares & Programming Languages


Software is written in some programming language. Programming languages are how humans give instructions to computers, and these languages can vary depending on the task.


This code that humans write needs to be converted into machine code that computers understand. This is where compilers come in.


Operational Systems


The operating system is the most important logical part of a computer. It controls what the user interacts with and sees, and also controls how programs will run on the physical part of the computer.

As a result, developing a good operating system can be a significant challenge.


Software Engineering


This leads us to software engineering, where you write a set of instructions determining the computer’s actions. Creating software needs to be as efficient as possible and free of errors. Some of the best practices people follow to build good software are object-oriented design, unit testing, and version control.


“Creating good software is a form of art because you need to convert your creative ideas into logical instructions.”


Other highly important areas worth mentioning are networking, where multiple computers communicate to solve a specific problem, data management in which computers store and manage large amounts of information, and performance, which focuses on analyzing how computers perform in different tasks.


Applications


This is the part where computers can solve real-world problems, and this is present in various programs, apps, and websites we use in our daily lives.


When you go on a trip, you want to have the best trip money can buy, solving an optimization problem. Optimization problems consist of finding the best or most efficient path, potentially saving millions of dollars for companies.


This is related to the Boolean Satisfiability Problem, where you consider whether a logical formula can be satisfied or not. This was one of the first problems considered almost impossible to solve.


Artificial Intelligence


Artificial intelligence is one of the main fields of research in computer science. Computers have the capacity to extend our thoughts, meaning developing computers that can think for themselves.


Machine Learning


One of the study areas of artificial intelligence is machine learning. Its main function is to create algorithms and techniques that allow computers to learn based on large amounts of information.


With this, they use the learning for something useful, such as making decisions on their own or classifying something.


Computer Vision


Another field of computer science is computer vision, making computers see the same way humans do, using image processing techniques.


Natural Language Processing


As the name suggests, natural language processing aims to make computers understand and communicate using human language or process vast amounts of information using words.


This uses knowledge representation, where information or words are organized according to their relationships, such as words with similar meanings.


Big Data


Machine learning algorithms have improved due to the immense amount of data available. Big Data’s function is to analyze and manage these large amounts of data.


We also receive even more information due to the Internet of Things, including information and communications between objects through the internet.


Hacking


Hacking is considered by many to be illegal, and most of the time, it is. It involves trying to find vulnerabilities in computer systems to gain access to any available information. This can be used for both good and bad purposes.


Computer-Human Interaction


The goal of human-computer interaction is to make the use of systems and computers as easy and intuitive as possible.


Other fields worth mentioning are augmented reality, virtual reality, and telepresence. These areas aim to improve our experience with reality.


Finally, we have Robotics, providing computers with a physical form.


Conclusion


The goal of this article was to briefly introduce the different fields of computer science and some of its applications.


Computer Science is an area that is still evolving, although the physical aspect is reaching a limit as scientists are having difficulties in reducing the size of transistors.


Computers and technology have had a significant impact on humans, and it will be even more interesting to see how far it will go.

Let's start this one with a thought experiment, have you ever got to a point while trying to be productive or looking for ways to be productive, where, for instance, instead of studying you were watching a YouTube video on how to study effectively?


It is funny when we think about it.


Most people get stuck in this never-ending loop of trying to be productive, trying to find the perfect study routine or the perfect hour to code, but the truth is that there is no such thing other than just doing the thing that the back of your mind is telling you to do.


And the same logic applies to becoming a so-called “10x developer” or a hyper-productive developer.


You won't be able to write code without someone guiding you by hand if you don't understand and break free of a couple of simple concepts.


What Is A 10x Developer?


As you might have figured out already, a 10x developer is a developer that is 10x more productive and efficient when compared to regular developers.


Putting it simply, if a regular developer takes 10 hours to solve a problem, a 10x developer will take 1 hour to solve the same problem.


But like always, there is a catch.


The 10x Developer is Just a Myth


I remember back in the PlayStation 2 era, when playing GTA San Andreas most people, including me, thought that if you went to a specific location on the map you would find the Bigfoot.


The information quickly spread across many players, because in those days we only had forums on which people could communicate, so there weren't a lot of ways to verify if the game had this mythical creature.


But unfortunately, that was just a myth.


Just like the concept of the 10x developer.


To clarify though, we might have developers among us who can produce 10 times more code than the average developer.


But don't get your expectations too high, perhaps they are not what you expect them to be.


So just like with the Bigfoot myth from GTA San Andreas, some actions led to the creation of the myth of the 10x developer.


And according to my fellow Justin Etheredge, here are a few, let's say, archetypes, or in other words engineers that helped build the foundation of the 10x myth.


The One Who Prefers The Path Of Least Resistance


We all have that one guy in school who for the group project, always did the introduction and bibliography and called it a day.


The same thing happens with software engineering, there is the person who is always picking the easiest tasks out of the board.


So when the day ends the project leader looks at the board that is full of completed tasks by the same person and says: “Wow, you put in the hours today”.


The One Who Tries To Reinvent The Well


This one is like creating an autonomous robot just to make a simple sandwich.


People always consider these types of developers as 10x developers just because they like to make a lot of noise about any problem they are solving.


But at the end of the day, it's just complex solutions to simple problems.


Don't get me wrong, it's awesome to have someone who can formulate and execute complex ideas, we just need to know in which situations this will be useful.


The Half Finisher


“It is better not doing something than doing something in half”.


I think we all did this at some point in our lives, even with coding.


Marking a task as complete, even though you did not complete the task is like twisting the fabric of reality or playing with the third law of Newton, action-reaction.


Eventually, all that uncompleted work will catch up to you, creating a huge mess and making other developers stop their work just to fix something that could’ve been easily avoided.


The One Whos Keeps On Coding


In all human endeavors, most of the time quantity does not equal quality.


Of course, there are situations like a deadline for a project that will require you to write code faster.


But nine out of ten times rushed code ends up with poor quality. Having to rely on teammates to clean up afterward.


Then we have a snowball effect.


Why do We Have A Concept Like This?


I just listed a few examples of programmers who give credit to the 10x developer myth, but that does not explain the full scope of the situation.


You might be wondering why or how a concept like this came into existence.


We can look back 70 years and start to see the field of software engineering coming to life in the form of assembly language and other low-level languages. People were starting to write code during World War II.


So it is definitely safe to say the programming goes back a while now.


Throughout the years we had so many people writing code, building stuff, and helping the industry grow and at the same time, the concept of a 10x developer was gradually rising.


So you can imagine a few developers coming and going, each and every single one of them having a unique way of being, whether is writing code or just their personality.


The first reason that might have led to the creation of the 10x myth is that developers with more experience write far more code than other developers with less experience, making the more experienced ones stand out in the long term


Another reason for that is simply the visibility.


Bill Gates is not a better coder just because he created Microsoft, Mark Zuckerberg is also not a better coder just because he developed Facebook, and the same applies to anyone.


Success stories like the ones from above might guide you in the wrong direction, giving too much credit to extraordinary achievements.


In any science, whether in chemistry, physics, or medicine, we all have this tendency to put certain people on pedestals, especially with coding when we all give too much credit to a single individual and forget all the teamwork along the way.


Lastly, it is important to point out that since programming is mostly a creative endeavor, we still do not have practical ways to quantify metrics, unlike a player in a soccer match in which we can tell if the player played well based on how many goals he scored or how many passes he got it right.


What it Really Means to be a Hyper-Productive Developer


In any realm of human endeavor, being productive often will lead you to subjects like:


Manage your time effectively, set clear tasks, or be clear about your goals.


While all those topics are valid, It took me some time to understand this straightforward thing:


All these tips and tricks will most certainly lead to some form of procrastination because, at the end of the day, you are not focusing on getting the work done, you are just worried about implementing methods and tips that will offer you a false feeling of job done.


So how can you become a developer who will stand out from the crowd?


One of the simplest and most common, yet effective, advice is to always receive new knowledge, and never stop learning. Look at challenges as opportunities for growth.


Technology is crazy, it never stops changing. You cannot just learn HTML, CSS, and JavaScript and call it a day. You must go beyond that, learning new frameworks, tools, and libraries.


You must always be a sponge when it comes to new information, but at the same time, you also need to apply this new information to your life, always expanding your horizon.


Look For These Type Of Developers Below


Earlier in the article, I presented to you some archetypes of developers that might reinforce the 10x myth.


But now that you know which types of developers you want to avoid, you may be wondering what are some developers that will definitely add value to my team.


You can also take this list as an inspiration for becoming one of them.


The Interrogator


“The man who asks a question is a fool for a minute, the man who does not ask is a fool for life.”


I remember in my first job as a developer I had this mentor who would always explain how things work on a given project, so most of the time I would ask questions to him, so whenever I didn't ask any questions he would always point out that maybe I did not fully understand something.


People often assume that asking questions shows signs that you do not completely understand the subject at hand.


But asking questions is the most efficient way to understand anything in life. This is the way that developers like this will go about solving any problem.


This allows the person to understand every single aspect of the problem, leaving no stone unturned.


I Am A Simple Man


These are the types of developers that can take any kind of complex problem and solve it in the most simple and unimaginable way possible. I bet that those kinds of developers could solve quantum gravity in a cave with a box of scraps.


Having developers who can solve complex problems in simple ways can make a positive impact on your team.


The Ones That Fix The Problem Instead


Those types of developers will go a long way to solve any problem but they are hard to come by.


You can argue that most of the time this is not the best practice and perhaps it is counter-intuitive. But there are times when instead of trying to find a solution, we might as well redesign the problem in a way that fits the current context of the problem we are trying to solve.


The Obsessor


Some people say that a problem is a chance for you to do your best, while others say that to solve a problem we need to dig at the roots instead of hacking the leaves.


And that is incredibly true for the types of developers who just won't give up when working through a problem.


Those types of developers wake up and go to sleep thinking about the problem and they will not rest until the problem is not solved.


Knows One Thing At Its Full Length


Let me ask you a question:


Is it better to know 25% about 4 different things or know 100% about 1 thing?


You simply cannot compete with the developers that chose the latter.


That is the reason you should always look for someone with a deep understanding of a subject, usually that person will be able to solve any problem in that realm.


Slows Down To Speed Up


“Give me six hours to chop down a tree and I will spend the first four sharpening the axe”.


That is also true when it comes to writing code.


As you may know, writing code is the easiest part.


The challenge lies in coming up with the solutions for the problem you are trying to solve.


Developers like this are exceptional because they don't just go with the first solution that comes to their mind, they wait, research, and try to find the best practices


And only after this extensive process they will write the code and declare the problem solved.


Bullseye


it's been proved that 2 hours of focused work is better than 8 hours of unfocused work.


We have been seeing a lot of news about people getting easily distracted because of social media, phones, or anything that might grab our attention.


As a developer who spends most of the day staring at a screen, we can easily fall into this trap, it all starts with checking email but then when we see, another full hour goes by.


With that in mind, in today's world just knowing how to code is not enough, it is a must to be able to block all distractions and lock into the flow.


When it comes to productivity and getting the work done, these types of developers are the ones who usually excel at that.


Wrapping Up


I hope that at this point you are more familiar with all the different types of developers in today's world.


With this in mind, perhaps you might want to avoid a few types.


But at the end of the day, they all contribute in some way to the community.


See you in the next one.

When we come across the word “design” we often think about something specific, the process of creating and planning something or solving a problem, always with a goal in mind, just like placing the last piece in a giant puzzle.


Perhaps it is safe to say that designs should be specific to the problem at hand, and at the same time, they should also address future issues that might or might not occur.


As you dive into the Object-Oriented World you will start to notice a lot of experienced developers tell you not to reinvent the wheel, in other words, use solutions that worked for them in the past.


So, once you start doing this, you will eventually realize that exist patterns in those same solutions, and you will start to find relations that you didn't know existed before, allowing you to take advantage of these relations to enhance your workflow and coding experience.


But you might be wondering what exactly is a design pattern, how it works, and why it is so important in the coding world. So, without wasting any time let's get straight into answering those questions.


What is a Design Pattern?


You know the saying: “If there is a sign, there is a history behind it”.


As I mentioned, before every design pattern there was once a problem.


Design patterns are solutions to recurring problems, Design Patterns provide you with descriptions of how to solve a problem. Instead of having a boilerplate code ready to copy and paste.


They represent some level of abstraction that addresses common issues in the Object-Oriented realm.


What this means is that Design Patterns are not about specific lines of code or are attached to a programming language, they do not focus on the technical level, instead, they focus on the overall structure of the code, providing you with efficient ways to solve problems.


Design Patterns are divided into four fundamental categories.


Pattern Name


The first one, and perhaps the most important, is the name of the Pattern, as we know the purpose of a name is to uniquely identify a person, a concept, or any entity.


The Pattern name helps us instantly visualize and communicate the big picture of the problem, like what is this going to solve? What will it look like?


The Problem


The second one is the actual problem, before applying any pattern we must first understand the problem at its full length, and there are a couple of ways to go about understanding the problem.


Since each design pattern will focus on a particular Object-Oriented problem, we must have at the tip of our pen all the consequences, constraints, and trade-offs of its use. After getting all of this out of the way, the problem will become crystal clear.


The Solution


Having taken the time to understand the problem we can start thinking about the solution. The solution will often describe the elements that combined, make up the full design, that includes the relationships, classes, objects, and so on. Solution and problem will always work together when applying any pattern.


The Consequences


And the last one is the consequences. Since programming is all about trade-offs, there will be situations where, for instance, time will be extremely valuable, but using a faster solution might cost you more memory, so you must always be aware of consequences when choosing a pattern.


How to Know Which One To Use


It is funny that we have at our disposal formulas that can estimate the mass of a black hole. Still, sadly there is not a universal formula that can calculate the correct pattern you should use based on the problem that you are trying to solve.


Fortunately, we do have a few questions and methods that you can use that will tell you which design pattern you might want to apply to your specific needs.


First things first, you need to understand in theory what the pattern does and what problems it solves, for that, simply ask yourself this question: What is the nature of the problem?


Imagine that you need to create a system on which a library can manage and keep track of its books, allowing users to search for a specific book, check their availability, and borrow them.

.

After some time, the number of books and users kept increasing, making the system slow and deprecated, where books are not always updated and there are many existing issues.


A more experienced developer will look at this situation and immediately realize that we might have a structural problem, taking into regard the inefficiencies and inaccuracies when it comes to the data stored and the user experience.


After some digging, you might say: “I need a design pattern that will enhance the data organization and optimize the user interactions with the platform, making the system, once again, efficient”.


After researching everything you could about the problem and its solutions, you might want to start looking for real-world uses of the same design pattern you want to use. To achieve this goal, search for software, systems, or applications where the same pattern is currently being used.


This will give a pretty good understanding of how the pattern works, allowing you to see it working in practice.


And just like on any construction, before starting to put rocks and bricks together we must first create a blueprint of the building that will help translate the project from paper to the real world.


With software or applications, it is the same thing, we need to create some kind of graphical representation of all the classes and objects involved in the project, and for that, you can simply use something like an Object Modeling Technique.


The main reason for doing this is that we establish a solid foundation of the project structure, allowing everyone who is working on the project to have clarity and understanding at every step of the way.


Why & When Should You Learn Design Patterns


Eventually, at some point, every developer will come across Design Patterns. This could be through a class, an online course, a blog post, or maybe heard somewhere.


So I hate to be that guy in the group who is always saying obvious things, but when creating your first tic-tac-toe app or weather app, you may not want to use any Design Patterns.


This would be like using a fire hose to extinguish a match. It is just too much.


But after you have built some simple projects and are starting to get some confidence to build something big, Design Patterns will be extremely valuable to you at this point because they will improve your skills as a developer.


The other reason why you should learn Design Patterns is because they will allow you to use the best practices when it comes to building projects and at the same thing you will be able to communicate complex ideas on an architectural level.


If you are not convinced yet that you should invest some time in learning Design Patterns, here are a few reasons to learn:


The first one worth mentioning is the code quality.


Have you ever looked at some function or any piece of code and thought: “Wow, the person who wrote this is pretty smart!”.


You get a similar feeling because Design Patterns will provide a set of tools and solutions for you to write a more organized and cleaner code. Making it easier to understand and scale easily over time, where you can add or remove features with no trouble.


Another reason you might consider is the actual knowledge that you get from knowing all this stuff.


Nine out of ten jobs will ask for, at least, a fundamental knowledge of Object-Oriented principles, and that includes knowing about inheritance, polymorphism, encapsulation, and abstraction.


Having a solid foundation in Design Patterns will also improve your communication skills.


Communication is one of the most important pillars of any realm of human knowledge, and coding is no different. You can add so much value to a project when you are familiar with Design Patterns, in other words, you can translate your ideas and thoughts in a way that everyone can understand, ensuring a well-structured codebase.


Final Thoughts


To finish this up, perhaps it is safe to say that Design Patterns shaped many areas of software development and the way we write and think about code.


At the end of the day, most people think that learning about Design Patterns is just about writing better code or impressing a coworker, but there is a much bigger reason for that, Design Patterns allow you to tackle complex problems and convert them into elegant solutions.


That's where the beauty lies, the light at the end of the tunnel, the amazing feeling of solving a problem. And, as we go deeper and deeper into the sea of software development we start to notice some islands that contain gold, in other words, ways that you can expand your skills and knowledge, and for the journey of mastering your skills of Design Patterns I highly recommend the book that brought this article to live.
